How many are unwholesome?
For what purpose is unwholesomeness contemplated?

Namely, in terms of intrinsic nature, association, following, instigation, ultimate meaning, innate, skillful means, direct offerings, harm, attraction, antidotes, and obstruction, these are the meanings of unwholesomeness.
One part of the five aggregates, ten elements, and four sense bases is unwholesome.
In order to abandon attachment to the self combined with non-dharma, one contemplates unwholesomeness.

Unwholesome by intrinsic nature refers to the afflictions and secondary afflictions that can instigate evil conduct, excluding those associated with defiled intention and the afflictions of the form and formless realms, etc.ğŸ”½What are they again?
What is this again?ğŸ”½ğŸ”½

That is, those that are not innate in the realm of desire are unwholesome. If they are innate and can instigate evil behavior, they are also unwholesome. The rest are merely morally indeterminate with outflows.
The unwholesome by association are those dharmas associated with the passions and secondary passions.
The unwholesome by following are the propensities of those .
The unwholesome by instigation are the bodily and verbal actions instigated by them.
The unwholesome by ultimate truth is all that is transmigratory.
The unwholesome by birth is that which is born of the habit energy of unwholesome dharmas. As a result, one naturally delights in being unwholesome.
The unwholesome by means is that which is born of associating with bad friends, listening to wrong teachings, improper attention, and the performance of evil actions of body, speech, and mind.

The unwholesome of direct offering is when, having already taken refuge in a celestial assembly, one first has the intention to kill or is first motivated by wrong views, establishing temples and performing acts of offering, causing countless beings to extensively create non-virtue.
Establishing temples with the intention to kill first means in a place where cows, sheep, and so forth are killed to make offerings to celestial spirits.
Establishing temples with wrong views first means in a place where one undergoes suffering such as fasting to seek blessings and make wishes.
The unwholesome of harm is the various kinds of wrong conduct of body, speech, and mind in all places.

The unwholesome of attraction is when, after engaging in the various evil conduct of body, speech, and mind, one attracts unloved results and maturations in evil destinies and good destinies, either attracting or completing them. In evil destinies, one fully experiences the results and maturations of both attracting and completing. In the good destinies, one only experiences the results of completing, meaning that after being born there, one experiences the suffering of poverty due to the power of evil conduct.
The unwholesome that is to be eliminated refers to dharmas that are to be eliminated by various antidotes.
The unwholesome that is obstructive refers to dharmas that obstruct wholesome categories, such as counting and gathering with the assembly.
What is neutral?
How many are neutral?
For what purpose is neutrality investigated?

It means that which is neutral by nature, that which is neutral by association, that which is neutral by following, that which is neutral by instigation, that which is neutral by ultimate meaning, that which is neutral by birth, that which is neutral by means, that which is neutral by direct offering of service, that which is neutral by benefit, that which is neutral by enjoyment, that which is neutral by attraction, that which is neutral by antidote, that which is neutral by quiescence, and that which is neutral by outflow.
The whole of eight elements and eight sense bases, and part of the other aggregates, elements, and sense bases are neutral.
The eight elements are the five sense faculties of form, smell, taste, and touch, and the eight sense bases are also like this.
In order to abandon attachment to a self apart from good and bad dharmas, one contemplates neutrality.
The indeterminate nature refers to the eight sense bases of form, the part associated with the mind, the life faculty, the similarity of species, and the collections of names, phrases, and syllables.
The indeterminate related to association refers to the mind and mental factors associated with the collections of names, phrases, and syllables of one who is neither defiled nor pure.
One who is neither defiled nor pure shows a mind that is contrary to good and evil.
Associated with the collections of names, phrases, and syllables shows the meaning of their mode of activity, because they arise through the door of mental verbalization.

The indeterminate related to continuity refers to the habitual tendencies of those very conceptual proliferations, because the collections of names, etc., infuse the mind. Due to these habitual tendencies, conceptual proliferations arise later.
The indeterminate related to manifestation refers to the bodily and verbal actions manifested by those minds and mental factors included in them.
Included in them refers to the minds and mental factors included in the mode of activity of conceptual proliferation, such as the collections of names, etc., of one who is neither defiled nor pure.
The indeterminate of ultimate truth refers to space and non-analytical cessation.
The indeterminate obtained through birth refers to the karmic retribution of unwholesome and contaminated wholesome dharmas.
The indeterminate of skillful means refers to the dharmas of deportment and craftsmanship possessed by one whose mind is neither defiled nor wholesome.

One whose mind is neither defiled nor wholesome - this shows that the deportment, etc. produced by a mind that is neither defiled nor wholesome is indeterminate in nature. The rest, according to their respective circumstances, are either wholesome or unwholesome.

The indeterminate of making offerings in the present refers to, for example, a person who, with thoughts of reverence, takes refuge in a certain celestial assembly, refrains from thoughts of killing and wrong views, and establishes temples and makes offerings, causing innumerable beings to neither increase merit nor demerit in such places.
The indeterminate of benefiting refers to, for example, a person who, with a mind that is neither defiled nor pure, practices giving to their servants, wives, children, and so forth.
The indeterminate of enjoyment refers to when someone, without discrimination and with an undefiled mind, enjoys the requisites.
The phrase without a discriminating mind distinguishes the wholesome nature, while with an undefiled mind distinguishes the unwholesome nature.

The indeterminate of attraction refers to when someone, due to repeated practice in the skillful arts, in the future attracts a body of such characteristics, and by this body quickly perfects the practice of the skillful arts.
The indeterminate of counteraction refers to when someone, in order to cure illness and attain peace and happiness, with a discriminating mind takes good medicine.
The indeterminate of tranquility refers to the afflictions of the form and formless realms, because they are hidden and subdued by shamatha.
The indeterminate of outflow refers to the group of dharmas that arise together with the mind of transformation, because it is called the outflow of realization.

The dharmas that are associated with and coexistent with the mind of transformation are called the class of co-arising. These mental activities are called transformation because they give rise to transformation out of playfulness. They are indeterminate in nature. If they are for the sake of benefiting and comforting sentient beings, they should be known as good.
There are also those that manifest good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas. What are they?

It means that the Buddha and the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have attained the ultimate perfection, in order to benefit sentient beings, manifest various things. It should be known that among them, there is not a single dharma that truly exists.
As for manifestation, it means that the Buddha and the bodhisattvas, due to the power of those to be transformed, manifest various good, bad, and so forth.

As for manifesting bad, it means transforming into thieves and so forth, manifesting the cutting off of their heads and limbs, etc., in order to frighten other sentient beings and cause them to be subdued.ğŸ”½How are they bound to the desire realm?ğŸ”½How many are bound to the desire realm?
For what purpose do we contemplate those bound to the desire realm?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
That is, the wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate dharmas of one who has not yet eliminated desire are the meaning of being bound to the desire realm.
The phrase one who has not yet eliminated desire shows that one has not yet eliminated a portion of the desire realm's desires, which means that one has not yet realized samÄdhi.
If it were otherwise, the dharmas of the preliminary concentration would also be bound to the desire realm.
Why is this?

Because they have already attained samÄdhi, they delight in the cessation of craving. Because a portion of the coarseness that is to be eliminated is eliminated, it is also said that there is one separation from desire.
The external forms, etc., are not yet free from desire, and are also called bound to the desire realm because they are produced by the power of karma that increases.

The sÅ«tra says that they are produced by the power of karma that increases, which is shared by all sentient beings, in order to show that even those born in the form and formless realms still have karmic seeds that follow them because they are not yet free from desire.
Four elements, two sense bases in their entirety, and a portion of the other aggregates, elements, and sense bases are bound to the desire realm.
The four elements refer to the elements of smell, taste, nose, and tongue consciousness.
The two realms refer to the realms of smell and taste.
The remaining part refers to excluding the realms of form and formlessness, as well as uncontaminated dharmas.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that is dominant in desire, one contemplates the realm of desire.ğŸ”½What is the realm of form?
How many are the realm of form?
For what purpose is the realm of form contemplated?

It means the wholesome and indeterminate dharmas of one who has already abandoned desire for the desire realm but has not yet abandoned desire for the form realm. This is the meaning of the realm of form.
Excluding the previously mentioned four elements and two sense bases, the remaining aggregates, elements, and sense bases are part of the realm of form.
The part means excluding those bound to the desire and formless realms, as well as uncontaminated dharmas.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that has abandoned desire for the desire realm, one contemplates what is bound to the realm of form.
What is bound to the formless realm?
How many are bound to the formless realm?
For what purpose is the formless realm contemplated?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

That is, the wholesome and indeterminate dharmas possessed by one who has already abandoned desire for the form realm but has not yet abandoned desire for the formless realm are the meaning of being bound to the formless realm.
One part of the three realms, two sense bases, and four aggregates is bound to the formless realm.
The three realms refer to the mind realm, dharma realm, and mind consciousness realm.
The two sense bases refer to the mind sense base and dharma sense base.
The four aggregates refer to feeling and so forth.
There is also form produced by concentration, but it is not mentioned because it is small.
One part means excluding that which is bound to the desire and form realms, as well as the uncontaminated dharmas.
In order to abandon attachment to the self that has abandoned desire for the form realm, one contemplates that which is bound to the formless realm.

Furthermore, there is one kind of separation from desire, complete separation from desire, penetrating separation from desire, subduing separation from desire, and permanently destroying separation from desire.

As for one part and complete separation from desire, it is said based on the stages of abandoning desire. If one is able to abandon up to the eighth category of afflictions in this stage, this is one kind of separation from desire;
If one has already eliminated the ninth category, one is completely separated from desire.

Or, based on the detachment from the aggregates, if one is in the stage of learning, one is partially detached from desire. If one is in the stage of no-more-learning, one is completely detached from desire.
Detachment through penetration refers to detachment through the path of seeing.ğŸ”½Detachment through suppression refers to detachment through the worldly path.
Detachment through complete destruction refers to detachment through the supramundane path.

There are also ten kinds of detachment, namely, detachment by intrinsic nature, detachment by harm, detachment by support, detachment by superiority, detachment by ignorance, detachment by antidote, detachment by complete knowledge, detachment by complete cutting off, superior detachment, and unsurpassed detachment.
One should know that these ten kinds of detachment are the meaning of opposition, not necessarily the meaning of cutting off.
Detachment by intrinsic nature is called detachment by intrinsic nature.
Up to detachment by complete cutting off is called detachment by complete cutting off.
The meanings of these terms should be understood according to their specific types.ğŸ”½Natural detachment refers to the aversion to suffering and the dharmas that lead to suffering.
Detachment through harm refers to the aversion to the enjoyment of desires after the heat of passion has been released.
Detachment through sustenance refers to the aversion to delicious food after having eaten one's fill.

Superior detachment refers to the aversion to inferior states after having attained a superior state, just as in the world, after having attained the superior position of city lord, etc., one feels aversion to the inferior position of village chief, etc.
Foolish detachment refers to the aversion to the realm of nirvana on the part of foolish ordinary beings, because they do not understand its tranquil nature and are firmly attached to the aggregates.
Detachment through antidotes refers to the elimination of all afflictions through mundane and supramundane paths.

The abandonment of desire through thorough knowledge refers to the nature of aversion to dharmas in the three realms that is produced by those who have already attained the path of insight, because they have thoroughly known the nature of suffering in conditioned existence and are averse to all impure things.
The abandonment of desire through permanent severance refers to the nature of aversion that is produced by permanently severing the passions of each stage.
Superior abandonment of desire refers to the abandonment of desire of all worldly persons, sravakas, and pratyekabuddhas.
Unsurpassed abandonment of desire refers to the abandonment of desire of buddhas and bodhisattvas, because they do so in order to benefit and gladden all sentient beings.
What is the learner?
How many are learners?
With what aim is the learner investigated?
That which is good for one who seeks liberation is the meaning of learner.
One who seeks liberation is one who has already gone through the stage of accumulating provisions.
One should know that the stage of seeking to realize the factors of liberation is called the stage of accumulating provisions.
One part of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases is a learner.
The ten elements are the seven consciousness elements, the form element, the sound element, and the dharma element.
The four spheres are the form, sound, mind, and dharma spheres.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that seeks liberation, one contemplates those in training.ğŸ”½What is beyond training?
How many are beyond training?
For what purpose is beyond training investigated?
That which is good belonging to those who have attained the ultimate in the precepts is the meaning of beyond training.
Because arhats and others have attained the ultimate in the precepts, concentration, and wisdom, they are called beyond training.
One part of the ten elements, four spheres, and the aggregates is beyond training.

In order to abandon attachment to a self that is already liberated, one contemplates beyond training.ğŸ”½What is neither in training nor beyond training?ğŸ”½How many are neither in training nor beyond training?
For what purpose is neither in training nor beyond training investigated?

It means the wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate dharmas of ordinary beings, the defiled and indeterminate dharmas of those in training, the indeterminate dharmas of those beyond training, and the unconditioned dharmas, are the meaning of neither training nor post-training.
Ordinary beings means those who have not yet sought liberation, because they seek to cultivate training in the precepts, they are called those in training.
The defiled indeterminate of those in training means, as appropriate, the unwholesome and the obscured indeterminate are defiled, and the non-obscured indeterminate is indeterminate.
The eight sense bases and eight sense fields in their entirety, and part of the other aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields, are neither training nor post-training.
In order to abandon attachment to a self that is not liberated, one contemplates what is neither training nor post-training.
What is to be eliminated by insight?
How many are to be eliminated by insight?
For what purpose does one contemplate what is to be eliminated by insight?

That is to say, defiled views and doubts that arise from discrimination, the sphere of views and the sphere of doubt, and the fundamental and secondary passions that arise from views, etc., and the actions of body, speech, and mind that are set in motion by views, etc., and all the aggregates, sense bases, and elements of the evil destinies, etc., are the meaning of eliminated by the path of insight.
Among these, defiled views and doubts that arise from discrimination refer to the five views, etc., that are produced on the basis of hearing false doctrines, etc.
The words that arise from discrimination are used to exclude the innate view of a real self and the extreme view.
Question:
What are the characteristics of the extreme view?
Is it innate?
Answer:
It refers to the view of annihilation.
One who has already studied and realized the truths gives rise to such fear:
Now, where is my self?
The sphere of views refers to dharmas associated with views, and their seeds.
The sphere of doubt is also like this.
The passions and secondary passions that are produced by views, etc., are the part of craving, etc., that is associated with views, etc., and that has views, etc., as its objects.
The word â€œpartâ€ is used because the part that is to be eliminated by cultivation and the pure part are excluded.
One contemplates the elimination by insight in order to abandon attachment to a self that is perfected by views.ğŸ”½What is to be eliminated by cultivation?
How many are to be eliminated by cultivation?
For what purpose is that which is to be eliminated by cultivation investigated?
That which is to be eliminated by cultivation is the meaning of the impure dharmas that are opposed to that which is to be eliminated by insight, and that are obtained after the path of insight.
That which is opposed to that which is to be eliminated by insight is the remainder of the impure dharmas, excluding the defiled views, etc., that are produced by discrimination.
The words â€œimpure dharmasâ€ also include the good dharmas that are favorable to the penetration of the truths, because they are followed by the heavy burden of the passions.
All of the dharmas are eliminated by cultivation in part.
The word â€œpartâ€ is used because the part that is to be eliminated by insight and the pure part are excluded.
One contemplates that which is to be eliminated by cultivation in order to abandon attachment to a self that is perfected by cultivation.
How are they not to be eliminated?ğŸ”½How many are not to be eliminated?
For what purpose do we investigate what is not to be eliminated?
It means that all pure dharmas, excluding the wholesome of the stage of penetrating insight, are not to be eliminated.
Pure dharmas refer to the supramundane noble path, what is attained subsequently, and unconditioned dharmas.
The ten sense bases, four sense fields, and part of the aggregates are not to be eliminated.
Question:
What forms and sounds are not to be eliminated?
Answer:
The nature of the wholesome bodily and verbal actions in the body of one beyond training is not to be eliminated.
In order to abandon attachment to a perfected self, one investigates what is not to be eliminated.ğŸ”½What is conditioned arising?
How many are conditioned arising?
For what purpose do we investigate conditioned arising?

It means the characteristics, the analysis of the members, the brief inclusion of the members, the establishment of the conditions of the members, the establishment of the functions of the members, the inclusion of the members in the defilements, the meaning, the profundity, the distinctions, and the forward and reverse sequences. This is the meaning of conditioned arising.

The characteristics are: because of being produced by non-action, because of being produced by impermanence, and because of being produced by power and function, these are the characteristics of dependent origination.
Because of these characteristics, the Blessed One said:
Because this exists, that exists. Because this arises, that arises. Namely, ignorance conditions formations, and so on at length.
Because this exists, that exists shows the meaning of being produced by non-action.
Only because of the existence of conditions, conditioned dharmas can exist. Conditions do not have real functioning power to produce conditioned dharmas.
Because this arises, that arises shows the meaning of being produced by impermanence.
Dharmas that are not produced cannot be established as being produced by causes.
Ignorance conditions formations, and so on shows the meaning of being produced by power and function.
Although dharmas are without action and impermanent, not all results arise because of any one dharma as a condition.
Why is this?
Because the various dharmas have distinctions in their abilities.
For example, from the power of ignorance, the formations are able to arise, and so on up to from the power of birth, old age and death are able to arise.
As for the analysis of the members, it means analyzing dependent origination into twelve parts, because of the distinctions in the twelve members of dependent origination.
What are the twelve?
They are ignorance, formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, and old age and death.

As for the summary of the members, it means that the previously analyzed twelve members such as ignorance are now further summarized into four, namely the leading members, the led members, the producing members, and the produced members.
It is only by means of these four kinds of members that all the dharmas of the arising of causes and effects are summarized.
That is to say, at the time of the cause there are the leading and the led, and at the time of the effect there are the producing and the produced.
The leading members are ignorance, formations, and consciousness.
Because it causes the arising of future birth, it is the first to create the karma of the various practices, which then perfumes the mind.
The second is the stage of being led, which refers to name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling.
Because of the power of the perfuming of the mind, it can cause the seeds of name-and-form, etc., to be born in succession, one after another, in the future, and to increase and grow.
The third is the stage of being able to give birth, which refers to craving, grasping, and becoming.

Because of the power of craving for desire, etc., which has not yet been permanently eliminated, one first delights in the distinctions of good and evil practices in regard to desire, etc., and then arouses craving.
Because of the existence of consciousness that grasps existence, at the time of death, it will accord with the craving and manifest the perfuming of some karma.
The fourth is the stage of being born, which refers to birth, old age, and death.

Because of the manifestation of the perfuming of the distinctions of karma, one is born in a certain destiny, in a certain class of beings, etc., and then name-and-form, etc., are born in succession, one after another, as previously explained.
The words â€œbirth, old age, and deathâ€ are used to show that they are based on the three characteristics of the conditioned.
The reason that old age and death are established as one member is to show that there can be death apart from old age.
There can be no such thing as the six sense bases, etc., apart from name-and-form, etc., in a body born from a womb. Therefore, they are established as separate members.
As for the establishment of the conditions for the members, they are established as conditions on the basis of perfuming, attraction, reflection, and co-existence.

In accordance with what is appropriate, the conditions for the members are established on the basis of the four conditions. For example, ignorance with regard to the karmic forces is established as a condition by the cause of perfuming from previous lives, because the karmic forces that are born from the perfuming of that ignorance can create subsequent existence. At that time, the actual ignorance is able to attract and establish them,
so it is the condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent.
Because it attracts and establishes the various karmic forces, the continuity is born, and because one reflects on them,ğŸ”½.
It is the condition by the power of object, because the irrational thought of considering it to be supreme has as its object the state of ignorance, and because it exists simultaneously with it.

It is the condition as object because it is the object of the deluded thought that imagines it to be supreme, etc. It is the dominant condition because it causes the volition associated with it to create inverted objects.
In this way, all conditions should be understood according to their respective situations.
As for the function of the members, ignorance has two kinds of functions:
First, it causes sentient beings to be deluded about existence. Second, it acts as a condition for the karmic forces.
As for causing sentient beings to be deluded about existence, it means that because they are covered by it, they do not understand reality in the past, present, or future.
Because of this, they give rise to doubts such as these:
Did I exist in the past or not? and so on.
As for acting as a condition for the karmic forces, it means that because of its power, the karma of subsequent existence is able to increase.
The karmic forces have two kinds of functions:
First, they cause sentient beings to be differentiated in the various destinies. Second, they act as a condition for consciousness.
Causing sentient beings to be born in various destinies means that by the power of karma, sentient beings are born in various different destinies.
Acting as a condition for consciousness means that by the power of habitual tendencies, it enables the seeds of future name-and-form, etc. to grow.
Consciousness has two kinds of functions:
First, it holds the karmic bonds of all sentient beings; second, it acts as a condition for name-and-form.
Holding the karmic bonds of sentient beings means that it arises and ceases together with the habitual tendencies brought by karmic formations.
Acting as a condition for name-and-form means that because consciousness enters the mother's womb, name-and-form can grow.
Name-and-form has two kinds of functions:
First, it incorporates the individual bodies of sentient beings; second, it acts as a condition for the six sense bases.
Incorporating the individual bodies of sentient beings means that after birth, one is included in the category of sentient beings and has distinctions in the common lot.
Acting as a condition for the six sense bases means that because the previous factors such as name-and-form serve as a basis, the later factors such as the six sense bases can arise.
The six sense bases have two kinds of activity:
one is to cause the full completion of the body of sentient beings, and the second is to act as a condition for contact.
As for causing the full completion of the body of sentient beings, it is because after birth, the other faculties are not lacking.
Contact has two kinds of activity:
one is to cause sentient beings to revolve around the objects they experience, and the second is to act as a condition for feeling.
As for causing sentient beings to revolve around objects, it is because they experience the three kinds of objects that accord with pleasant feeling, etc. through this as a door.
Feeling has two kinds of activity:
one is to cause sentient beings to revolve around the results they experience, and the second is to act as a condition for craving.
As for causing sentient beings to revolve around the results they experience, it is because they experience the various karmic results that are loved, etc. through this as a basis.
As for acting as a condition for craving, it is because craving arises through this as a door, such as the desire for union with this.
Craving has two kinds of activity:
The first is that it causes sentient beings to transmigrate in birth and death; the second is that it acts as a condition for grasping.
As for causing sentient beings to transmigrate in birth and death, it is because the transmigration of birth and death continues without interruption due to its power.
As for acting as a condition for grasping, it is because craving, enjoyment, and desire serve as the gateway for the arising of craving for desire, etc.
Grasping has two kinds of activity:
The first is that it causes grasping of future existence, causing sentient beings to generate grasping consciousness; the second is that it acts as a condition for becoming.

As for causing grasping of future existence and generating grasping consciousness, it is in order for the continuity of future existence, such as the destiny of hell beings, etc., to be uninterrupted, and to enable the habitual tendencies of karma to become fixed.
As for acting as a condition for becoming, it is because the habitual tendencies of karmic activity are transformed due to its power.
Becoming has two kinds of activity:
The first is that it causes future existence to manifest for sentient beings; the second is that it acts as a condition for birth.
As for causing future existence to manifest, it is because it can attract the continuity of other destinies without interruption.
As a condition for birth, it is because the other members of the class are transformed by its power.
Birth has two kinds of activity:
The first is causing the successive arising of name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling of sentient beings. The second is acting as a condition for old age and death.
As for causing the successive arising of name-and-form, etc., it is because it can attract the distinctions of the later stages.
As for acting as a condition for old age and death, it is because the continuity of those [later stages] is transformed and destroyed due to this birth.
Old age and death have two kinds of activity:

The first is frequently causing the transformation of the time periods of sentient beings, destroying their youth and vigor. The second is frequently causing the transformation of the life spans of sentient beings, destroying their life spans.
As for the members being categorized as the three kinds of defilement, ignorance, craving, and grasping are categorized as the defilement of the passions.
Formations, consciousness, and becoming are categorized as the defilement of karma.
The remaining members are categorized as the defilement of birth.
Question:
Why is the member of consciousness categorized as the defilement of karma?
Answer:
Because it is manifested by the habitual tendencies of all conditioned phenomena.

As for the meaning, it means the meaning of no creator, the meaning of having causes, the meaning of being apart from sentient beings, the meaning of arising in dependence on others, the meaning of no function, the meaning of impermanence, the meaning of having moments, the meaning of the uninterrupted continuity of causes and effects, the meaning of the acceptance of the similarity of causes and effects, the meaning of the distinction of causes and effects, and the meaning of the certainty of causes and effects. This is the meaning of dependent arising.
It means that because it is apart from creators such as the Lord God, it is the meaning of no creator.
Because ignorance and so forth are the causes, it is the meaning of having causes.
Because there is no natural self, it is the meaning of being apart from sentient beings.
Because it arises in dependence on many conditions, it is the meaning of arising in dependence on others.
Because the function of many conditions is empty, it is the meaning of no function.
Because it is not eternal, it is the meaning of impermanence.
Because there is no abiding even for a moment after arising, it is the meaning of having moments.
Because the cause perishes in a moment and the effect is born in a moment, the two are simultaneous. This is the meaning of the continuity of cause and effect being uninterrupted.
Because the effect is not produced from everything, but only from a similar cause, this is the meaning of cause and effect being similar and mutually inclusive.
Because the effect is not produced from a single kind of cause, but from a cause that is not a single kind, this is the meaning of the distinction between cause and effect.
Because the effect is not received by another continuity, this is the meaning of the determination of cause and effect.
The profound means the profound of cause, the profound of characteristics, the profound of arising, the profound of abiding, and the profound of transformation. This is the meaning of the profound.
That is to say, it is precisely by means of the meaning of no creator, etc., that the five profundities of dependent origination are revealed.
The profundity of cause is revealed by two meanings, in order to counteract the theories of unequal causes and no causes.
The profundity of characteristics is revealed by one meaning, because it is the characteristic of no self.
The profundity of arising is revealed by two meanings, because although the dharmas of effects are produced from many conditions, they are not produced by those conditions.
Two meanings show the profundity of abiding: although there is no establishment, it appears as if there is abiding.
Four meanings show the profundity of transformation: the transformation of cause and effect is difficult to understand.

Moreover, although the dharmas of dependent origination are momentary and cease, abiding can be obtained; although there are no conditions of activity, conditions of capability can be obtained; although apart from sentient beings, sentient beings can be obtained; although there is no creator, the fruits of karma are not destroyed and can be obtained. Therefore, it is very profound.
The fruits of karma are not destroyed means that although internally there is no creator, there is the performance of karma and the experience of its fruits.
Moreover, all dharmas are not born from self, not born from other, not born from both, and not born without cause. Therefore, it is very profound.
Not born from self means that all dharmas are not created by themselves, because when they have not yet arisen, they have no self-nature.
Not born from other means that those conditions are not creators.
Not arising from both self and other means that it does not arise from these two causes.
Not arising from neither self nor other as a cause means that conditions have the ability to give rise to effects.
There is also a distinction, namely that arising depends on many conditions, so it is not self-produced.
Even though there are many conditions, without seeds it does not arise, so it is not produced by another.
Since both [self and other] are without activity, it is not produced by both.
Since seeds and many conditions both have the ability, it is not produced without a cause.
Therefore, it is said like this:

Because its own seeds exist, it does not arise from another. Because it depends on many conditions, it is not self-produced. Because it is without activity, it is not produced by both. Because it has the ability, it is not produced without a cause.

If the principle of dependent arising, which is neither self nor other, is still very profound when the two phrases are eliminated, how much more so when all four phrases are forgotten. Therefore, dependent arising is the most profound.

Distinctions means distinctions in the arising of consciousness, distinctions in internal death and rebirth, distinctions in the growth of external grains, distinctions in formation and destruction, distinctions in the sustenance of food, distinctions in the discrimination of desirable and undesirable destinies, distinctions in purity, and distinctions in spiritual powers. This is the meaning of distinctions.
Distinctions in the arising of consciousness means that the eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, and so forth.
Distinctions in internal death and rebirth refer to the world of sentient beings, meaning that ignorance and so forth as conditions are able to give rise to karmic formations and so forth.

Distinctions in the growth of external grains means that seeds are the condition for sprouts, sprouts are the condition for stems, and so forth, and in this way they gradually give rise to branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits.
Distinctions in formation and destruction mean that the power of the dominant conditions of the common karma of all sentient beings is the condition for the arising of the great earth and so forth.
Distinctions in the sustenance of food mean that the four kinds of food as conditions are the cause for the continuation of the existence of sentient beings in the three realms.
As for the distinction of the destinies of pleasure and pain, it is because good and evil actions are the conditions for going to good and evil destinies.

As for the distinction of purity, it is because the good roots conducive to liberation are the conditions for giving rise to the good roots conducive to penetration, and in this way, the path of insight and so forth gradually lead up to the attainment of the fruit of arhatship and so forth.
Or, it is because hearing the Dharma from another and proper attention are the conditions for giving rise to right view, which in turn leads up to the complete destruction of the contaminants.
As for the distinction of power, it is because realization is the condition for giving rise to the most excellent qualities such as the supernormal powers.
Based on these distinctions, one should explain in detail the conditioned arising of conditioned factors.

As for forward and reverse, it is because of the forward and reverse order of defilement and the forward and reverse order of purification. This is called the forward and reverse order of conditioned arising.

As for the forward and reverse order of defilement, it is explained in accordance with the order of evolution, namely, ignorance conditions karmic formations, and so forth, which is explained in forward order.
Or it is explained based on the established truth, namely, the suffering of old age and death, the accumulation of old age and death,
the cessation of old age and death, and the practice leading to the cessation of old age and death. Such explanations are given in reverse order.
The pure forward and reverse order means that because ignorance ceases, karmic formations cease. Such explanations are given in forward order.
Due to the absence of what does old age and death not exist?
Due to the cessation of what does old age and death cease?
Such explanations are given in reverse order.
One should contemplate the meaning of the arising of dependent origination in this way.
All are dependent origination, except for a part of the dharma realm and dharma element, namely the unconditioned dharmas.

For what purpose does one contemplate conditions?
The meaning of a condition is as cause, as the immediately preceding condition, as the object, and as the dominant condition.
All are conditions.
One contemplates conditions in order to abandon attachment to self as the cause of dharmas.
As for causal conditions, they refer to the Älaya consciousness and wholesome habitual tendencies, which serve as causal conditions for contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas in sequence.
The Älaya consciousness is of two kinds: matured and active.
The matured refers to the causal conditions for innate dharmas.
The active refers to the causal conditions for acquired dharmas and for future Älaya consciousnesses.
Moreover, the active Älaya consciousness refers to the perfuming and accumulation of the presently operating evolving consciousnesses, etc. in this lifetime.

As for wholesome habitual tendencies, they refer to the habitual tendencies of the stage conducive to penetration. Because these habitual tendencies use the dharmas that flow out from supramundane realization as their objects and are born from them, they can serve as causal conditions for supramundane dharmas.
Moreover, the characteristics of causal conditions are in terms of intrinsic nature, distinctions, assisting, equal practice, increase, obstruction, and inclusion.

It should be known that in this [treatise], the meaning of the causal condition is explained by means of six kinds of characteristics such as intrinsic nature, namely, the two phrases establishing the intrinsic nature and distinctions establish the efficient cause, and the remaining phrases establish the coexistent cause, the associated cause, the homogeneous cause, the universal cause, and the retributive cause in sequential order.
Intrinsic nature refers to the intrinsic nature of the efficient cause. The efficient cause is established based on the intrinsic nature of the cause.
It should be known that all causes are subsumed within the efficient cause. In order to illustrate the meaning of distinctions, the accompanying cause, etc., are further separately established.
Distinctions refer to the distinctions of the efficient cause, which are generally of twenty kinds:

1. The efficient cause of arising, which refers to the combination of consciousnesses with regard to consciousness. Because the present existence of consciousness that did not previously exist is brought about by this combination.

2. The efficient cause of abiding, which refers to food with regard to sentient beings who have already been born and those seeking birth. Because the continuity of existence of those who have already been born is maintained by its power.
3. The efficient cause of bearing, which refers to the great earth with regard to sentient beings. Because it supports them and prevents them from falling.
The fourth is the illumination-maker, which is like a lamp in relation to visible forms, because it illuminates and removes darkness and obstructions.
The fifth is the transformation-maker, which is like fire in relation to fuel, because it causes the continuity of the fuel to transform.
The sixth is the separation-maker, which is like a sickle in relation to what is cut, because it causes the connected object to become two parts.
The seventh is the transformation-maker, which is like the wisdom of craftsmanship in relation to gold and silver objects, because it transforms their original shape into something different.
The eighth is the conviction-maker, which is like smoke in relation to fire, because one infers its presence through this.
The ninth is the manifestation-maker, which is like a thesis, reason, and example in relation to what is to be established, because one attains correct ascertainment through these.
The tenth is the attainment-maker, which is like the noble path in relation to nirvÄá¹‡a, because one realizes it through this.
The eleventh is the expression-maker, which is like names, thoughts, and views, because one gives rise to expressions in accordance with names, grasping at characteristics, and attachment.

The twelfth is the condition of requirement, i.e., that which is required in order to generate desire for something, like hunger and thirst in the seeking of food and drink. It is a condition because it is the cause of the generation of desire.
The thirteenth is the condition of attraction, i.e., a remote condition, like ignorance as a condition of old age and death, because it attracts future existence through a series of transformations.
The fourteenth is the condition of generation, i.e., a proximate condition, like ignorance as a condition of the karmic forces, because it generates future existence immediately.

The fifteenth is the condition of support, i.e., the remaining conditions, like field, water, fertilizer, etc., as conditions of the production of grain, etc. Even though the grain, etc., is produced from its own seeds, these other conditions increase its power.

The sixteenth is the condition of revelation, i.e., a condition that is in conformity with its result, like a minister who serves the king and delights him. It is a condition because it reveals and attracts.

The seventeenth is the condition of determination, i.e., a condition that is specific, like the conditions of the five destinies as conditions of the results of the five destinies, because it determines specific results.

The eighteenth is the cooperative condition, which is a condition that is a cooperative condition, like the faculties, objects, and the mind that is the immediately antecedent and similar condition, which are conditions as the cause of consciousness. This is because the production of consciousness must await the cooperation of other conditions.
The nineteenth is the contradictory condition, which is a condition that is a contradictory condition, like hail is to a crop, because it damages it.
The twentieth is the noncontradictory condition, which is a condition that is a noncontradictory condition, like the absence of any obstacle to a crop, which is the opposite of the preceding.

Among these twenty kinds of conditions as cause, only consciousness, the union of the faculties and their objects, etc., are mentioned because they are the most important and because the wise can infer the rest from them.

The second type of condition is the condition as a similar and immediately antecedent state. This means that dharmas that are born together are necessarily not lacking in each other, like the four great elements and the form derived from them, which are similar and immediately antecedent conditions for each other, in accordance with the case. This is not so for all aggregates, which are not necessarily composed of the four great elements and form derived from them.
If a certain place contains a certain amount of these elements, they must be born together and cannot be separated from each other.
Equal activity means that all dharmas have equal activity in their objects and are never lacking, like mind and mental factors.
In the previous discussion of the accompanying factors, the establishment of the coexistent cause was only said to be the great elements and the form derived from them;
this is merely a brief indication of the main points, because mind and mental factors are by nature inseparable and are also included in the accompanying factors.
If that is so, then one should not establish the corresponding cause separately, because the various minds and mental factors are also included in the coexistent cause.

Although this is so, there is still a difference in meaning, because all dharmas have equal activity in their objects and are mutually inseparable, and because of this equal activity, the corresponding cause is established, not just the coexistent meaning, like mind and mental factors.

Augmentation means that because of cultivating good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas in the past, it can cause good, etc., dharmas in the future to be increasingly superior and arise one after another.
Cultivating in the past means the meaning of frequently practicing in the present.

These dharmas are similar and act as causes for growth, and for that reason they are established as homogeneous causes.

This universal cause not only causes similar passions to grow.
Why is this?

If one cultivates greed, etc., to a greater or lesser extent, it causes all the passions such as hatred, etc., to continue, to grow, and to become fixed. Because of this, one is deeply fettered and obstructed from obtaining liberation. For this reason, universal causes are established.
As for the statement that â€œthey attract,â€ this means that good and impure dharmas attract their own substance and are therefore retributive causes.
